STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 25, 2025
Lauryn Ritchie
Let's Talk About it Girl's Home III
615 W. Lovell,
Kalamazoo, MI, 49007
Re: License #: CI390403045
SI #: 2025SIC0000368
Dear Lauryn Ritchie:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way the area manager at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
427 East Alcott St.
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
(269) 251-2471
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000368
Special Investigation Intake Date: February 12, 2025
License #: CI390403045
Licensee Group Organization: Let's Talk About It CMH Services, PLLC
Licensee Designee: Tonya Moore
Chief Administrator: Lauryn Ritchie
Agency Name: Let's Talk About it Girl's Home III
Agency Address: 615 W. Lovell
Kalamazoo, MI 49007
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 09/17/2026
Capacity: 14
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
3/06/2025 Teams MDHHS Disposition held.
2/18/2025 Phone Interview
2/13/2025 Phone Interview
2/12/2025 Face to Face Interview
2/12/2025 Face to Face Documentation received or sent;
Entrance Conference; Unannounced
Visit; Incident Notification; Special
Investigation Initiation; Interview
2/12/2025 Email Incident Notification
2/12/2025 Email Documentation received or sent
1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code &
CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement.
Section
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff had personal items which included medication on kitchen
table which youth took.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the Hospital on
2/12/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A
reported coming to the hospital yesterday (2/11/25) after taking
medication Youth A took from Staff 1. Youth A reported the
medication was Ibuprofen and Acetaminophen and “taking 10-12
pills”. Youth A reported not swallowing the pills but did place the
pills in Youth A’s mouth. Youth A also reported Staff 1 held Youth
A’s jaw not allowing Youth A to swallow the pills, so Youth A spit
the pills into Staff 1’s hand. Youth A reported sitting at the kitchen
table with Staff 1 when Youth A noticed Staff 1’s pills sitting on the
table and Youth A was feeling as if she didn’t want to live any
longer therefore, Youth A grabbed the pills and put them in her
mouth. Youth A reported Staff 1 had a purse and had removed the
pills from the purse to take a pill. Youth A reported Staff 2 was in
the room doing dishes at the time and had Staff 2’s back turned to
Youth A and Staff 1 who were sitting at the table. Youth A
reported being on “one-to-one” supervision because of suicidal
thinking over the past couple of days and Staff 1 was the staff with
the “one-to-one” supervision responsibility. Youth A reported
attempting self-harm on Saturday (2/8/25) and was taken to the
Emergency Room. Youth A also reported writing a suicidal note,
cut Youth A’s arm, and tied a shirt around Youth A’s neck before
Law Enforcement broke into Youth A’s barricaded room. Youth A
reported feeling safe at the facility and has no issue with treatment
by staff. Youth A also reported having individual therapy weekly
and group therapy weekly. Youth A reported working on trauma
narrative in therapy and this bringing up issues that are difficult for
Youth A to deal with. Youth A also reported having a safety plan
and is taking a variety of medication to help stabilize moods and
depression. Youth A reported staff check for cheeking when taking
medication and all medication is locked in a cabinet in a locked
office at the facility.
2

Administrator 1, Administrator 2, and Administrator 3 were
interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 2/12/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Administrator 1 reported
calling Central Intake to get approval to send Youth A into
treatment at the hospital. She also reported being asked why
Youth A needed this increase in treatment and responding that
Youth A is displaying suicidal ideation and Youth A’s doctor
suggested the increase. Administrator 1 reported not saying
anything about Youth A’s attempt to take pills. They reported
having the incident on video and will provide the recording. They
also reported Staff 2 was in the kitchen when the incident took
place and Staff 1 and Staff 2 both contacted Administrator 1 “right
away” following the incident. They reported reviewing the video
recording and observed Youth A take the pills and place them in
Youth A’s mouth for about “30 seconds” before spitting the pills
out of Youth A’s mouth. They also reported Youth A only put
Tylenol in Youth A’s mouth and then only a “couple” of pills. They
reported Youth A started to become dysregulated over issues with
Youth A’s mother from the past on Friday which caused the “one-
on-one” supervision to begin. They also reported about Youth A’s
self-harming event on Saturday and Youth A’s release from the
hospital on Sunday. Youth A has been on this increased level of
supervision since then. They reported the policy for staff’s
personal belongings is that these items must be left in the locked
office and not brought out of the locked office. Staff are not to
have personal items on them when working. They also reported if
Staff 1 needed something from her purse/bag then Staff 1 should
have asked for relief from Staff 2, went into the office to obtain
what she needed and then left the personal items in the purse/bag
in the locked office. They reported going over this policy with Staff
1 yesterday and providing disciplinary action for this breaking of
policy. Administrator 1 reported Youth A kept asking for Ibuprofen
for emotional pain and saying Youth A wanted to die and not be in
the program anymore. Administrator 1 reported because of these
actions by Youth A, Administrator 1 made the decision to take
Youth A to the hospital for an evaluation. Administrator 1 reported
Youth A informed Administrator 1 that the emotional pain was
because of Youth A’s trauma narrative which involved Youth A’s
mother not reaching out to Youth A.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
2/12/2025 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1
reported being the “one-to-one” staff for Youth A the day of the
incident and they were sitting at the kitchen table eating breakfast.
Staff 1 also reported having her purse at the table because she
3

was trying to organize the purse and find her journal. She reported
having Tylenol and ibuprofen in a zip lock bag and sat it on the
table. Staff 1 reported Youth A “snatched” the bag and opened the
bottle of Tylenol taking about 4 pills and placing them in Youth A’s
mouth. Staff 1 reported not wanting Youth A to swallow the pills,
so Staff 1 placed her hand under Youth A’s chin. This move
caused Youth A to spit the pills out into Staff 1’s hand. Staff 1
reported switching out with Staff 2 and putting her purse in the
locked office. Staff 1 reported placing her purse in the office when
first coming to work but then taking the purse out to look for the
journal. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 turned around after hearing Staff 1
say something about the pills and assisting Staff 1. Staff 1
reported receiving a write-up for the violation of the policy about
personal items and being told she needs more training.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 2/13/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. She reported being the
assigned staff for Youth A’s one-to-one supervision the day of the
incident. She also reported Staff 1 switched with Staff 2 so Staff 2
could finish the dishes. Staff 2 reported hearing Staff 1 tell Youth
A to put something down and when turning around to see, Staff 2
observed Staff 1 getting a bottle of pills from Youth A and Youth A
grabbing a second bottle of pills. She reported Youth A opened
the bottle and put some pills in Youth A’s mouth. She reported
Staff 1 squeezed Youth A’s mouth causing Youth A to spit the pills
out. Staff 2 reported knowing that all staff are to leave their
personal items in the locked office except for their phones and
keys. Staff 2 reported observing Staff 1’s purse but saying nothing
about it. Staff 2 reported Youth A was on suicidal watch (one-to-
one) which means a staff is to always be with Youth A. She
reported this began over the weekend when Youth A became
dysregulated and attempted self-harm after barricading Youth A in
Youth A’s bedroom.
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 2/18/2025. She
reported having no further information.
Walk-through:
A walk through was completed at the facility and the areas the
incident took place in were inspected. There is nothing out of
order in this area nor the facility in general.
Video Recording:
The recording opens with a view from the top of the wall onto the
kitchen table, taking in the whole of the kitchen (sink, counter tops,
door leading outside, and refrigerator). Youth A is observed sitting
4

alone at the table when Staff 1 walks into the view and places
what appears to be a purse/bag on the table and pulls out a see-
through plastic bag. Staff 1 removes what appears to be pills from
the plastic bag and places them in her mouth before taking a drink
from a water bottle. Staff 1 appears to place the plastic bag in
front of her on the table and sits down to the right of Youth A at
the table. Staff 2 walks into the room and goes to the countertop
left of the sink before moving to the sink and turning her back to
Youth A and Staff 1 who remain sitting at the table. Staff 1 places
the bottles of medication back in the plastic bag and places the
plastic bag on the table in front of her again. Staff 1 picks up her
purse/bag and Youth A quickly grabbed the plastic bag of
medication. Staff 1 holds out her left hand in a gesture of wanting
the plastic bag back. Staff 2 turns around from the sink just after
Youth A appears to open a bottle. Staff 1 appears to try and grab
the plastic bag from Youth A who turns away from Staff 1. Youth A
hands a bottle to Staff 1, Youth A appears to place something in
Youth A's mouth as Staff 2 runs towards Youth A. Both staff (Staff
1 and Staff 2) confront Youth A who is refusing to give what they
are wanting before Staff 1 appears to place her hand under Youth
A’s jaw. Youth A spits something out of Youth A’s mouth as Staff 1
removes her hand before standing up with her purse/bag and
walking to the trash can, appearing to throw something out. Staff 2
removes the trash bag where the pills were placed, and Staff 1
appears to be washing her hand.
Documents Reviewed:
Incident Report for Youth A dated 2/10/25 at 8:35 am. This
document outlines the incident outlined in the allegations of this
investigation. It is documented that Staff 1 brought her bag/purse
out of the kitchen and Youth A had taken Staff 1’s personal
medication off the table. It is also documented Youth A took
“around 10” Tylenol and placed them in Youth A’s mouth which
Youth A spit out the pills into Staff 1’s hand. It is documented
Youth A does not appear to have ingested any of the pills.
Interventions were provided (listened to music and 1:1
conversation. Youth A’s response is documented as Youth A
continued to ask for Ibuprofen for emotional pain and expressed a
desire to not live anymore. It is also documented Administrator 1
made the decision to have Youth A assessed at the hospital for
Suicidal Ideations.
Ascension Borgess Hospital Referral Recommendation and
Crisis Safety Plan Referral Recommendation dated 2/9/25 for
Youth A. This document outlines actions that are to be taken to
5

support Youth A’s safety. These actions include ensuring
weapons, lethal medications, or other means of self-harm are
secured. Other actions include, keep all recommended
appointments, take medication as prescribed, and notify your
provided if experiencing side effects from the medication. It is
documented that if a crisis occurs, a list of actions is noted.
Triggers, warning signs, coping strategies, and people Youth A
can contact for help are listed.
LTAI Home Safety Plan for Youth A dated 2/9/25. It is
documented Youth A is to remain in arm’s length of one staff at all
items and the staff assigned to Youth A is not to tend to the needs
of any other youth unless switched out by other staff. It is also
documented when Youth a uses the restroom, a body check is to
be completed to ensure Youth A has no items for self-harm prior
to Youth A going into the restroom. Staff are also to check the
restroom prior to Youth A entering to ensure no glass, sharps, or
other items that could be used for self-harm are present. Staff are
to stand near the door and complete prompts for a response every
few minutes. Youth A is not to have kitchen chores until this safety
plan is lifted. Youth A is not to use any “sharps” and staff can
complete the task for Youth A. Staff are always to sit outside
Youth A’s bedroom whenever Youth A is in the room and in a
position Youth A can be visibly seen. Staff are to use a flashlight
for bed checks. Youth A’s door will always remain open. Support
steps are documented to help Youth A cope with unwanted
emotional issues.
LTAI Code of Ethics dated 1/2025. This document outlines the
ethical responsibilities for LTAI employees. It is documented that
“employees keep their personal items off the premises or locked in
the staff office”. It is also documented that the office doors should
be s hurt and always locked.
HR record for Staff 1 was reviewed. Staff 1 was hired on
10/15/24. Documentation indicates Staff 1 signed
acknowledgment of the Code of Ethics on 11/14/24 and is up to
date on training (orientation documented as completed on
11/14/24). There is one disciplinary action documented in her
personnel file. This disciplinary action is dated 2/11/25 and is
identified as a written warning. The circumstances that lead to this
written warning is Staff 1 not adhering to the LTAI Code of Ethics
by leaving her purse and medication unguarded. This action
allowed Youth A who was on suicide watch to pick up Staff 1’s
medication and take a handful of the medication. Staff 1 is
expected to meet the standard of ensuring the safeguarding of all
6

personal belongings either off the premise or locked in the staff
office. This document is signed by Staff 1 on 2/11/25.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as evidence by interviews
with staff, youth and video recording review. Staff 1 did not follow
the policy that staff are to leave personal items in the locked office
when working at the facility. This action by Staff 1 allowed Youth A
to obtain medication and attempt a self-harming behavior. Staff 1
also failed to follow the safety plan (2/9/25) which states staff are
to remain within an arm’s length of Youth A “at all times”.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical Assistance was offered to the facility to monitor Staff 1
more closely. Because Staff 1 is a newer staff, she should not
have full responsibility for any youth without another staff being
present. All staff working with Staff 1 should be required to
complete an evaluation form after 1 month to ensure Staff 1 is
following all the expectations of a direct care staff at the facility.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2023C0000328 dated 6/30/23, CAP approved 7/28/23
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
3/14/25
______________________________________
Paul Fatato Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
3/25/2025
________________________________________
Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
